PaperTitle: Vis-A-Ware: Integrating Spatial and Non-Spatial Visualization for Visibility-Aware Urban Planning

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Loads a 3D city model and a digital elevation model of the terrain for visibility analysis.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 5.1: The cityscape, where the visibility analysis is performed, is represented through a 3D city model and a digital elevation model of the terrain.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Organizes candidates, viewpoints, and VIMs into an n x m matrix, allowing lookup, transposition, and interaction in different major/minor modes.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 5.1: The entire evaluation data can be organized in an n x m matrix, where n and m are the numbers of candidates and viewpoints, respectively (see Fig. 3a).

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Calculates four Visual Impact Metrics (VIMs): landmark occlusion, candidate visibility, openness occlusion, and sky occlusion, based on false color renderings from various viewpoints.
Outputs: Raw VIM values for each candidate-viewpoint pair
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 5.2: We render the view from the respective viewpoint in false colors ... we get the area each component covers in the rendering from the current viewpoint.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Normalizes and bins the raw VIM values into percentage classes (low, medium, high, very high) for intuitive interpretation and comparison.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 5.3: After normalization, the VIM values are scaled to percentages and are binned into four classes: [0-25], [25-50], [50-75], and [75-100], which we denote as low, medium, high, and very high, respectively.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays the 3D geovirtual environment with candidate buildings, landmarks, and viewpoints, enabling spatial context exploration and candidate assessment.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.2: The 3D spatial view depicts a 3D geovirtual environment, consisting of a city model, landmarks, candidate buildings, and circular glyphs representing the positions of the viewpoints.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays circular glyphs at viewpoint locations showing the number of high-ranking candidates and their VIM distributions; size encodes coverage.
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.2: We display an aggregated view of the candidate distribution in each viewpoint as a circular glyph.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Tabular view showing candidates or viewpoints as rows and VIMs as columns; supports ranking, filtering, focus/context highlighting, and transpose between candidate-major and viewpoint-major modes.
Outputs: Tabular view of ranked candidates and viewpoints with VIM distributions
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.1: The TRV is a tabular view, where the rows either represent candidates or viewpoints... while the individual VIMs determine the columns of this table.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Displays side-by-side candidate renderings from selected viewpoints to support qualitative evaluation and comparison.
Inputs: Rendered images of candidates from viewpoints
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.3: We chose a filmstrip metaphor... to display the images which are associated with each evaluation in a side-by-side layout as depicted in Fig. 1c.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Allows users to focus on specific candidates or viewpoints, filter out less relevant entities, and transpose between candidate-major and viewpoint-major modes in the TRV.
Outputs: Updated TRV with filtered candidates/viewpoints and focus-context distinction
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.1.2: The workflow supported by the TRV is a sequence of focus, filter, and transpose interactions which allow users to investigate evaluations with respect to candidates and viewpoints.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Allows users to navigate to a selected viewpoint in the 3D spatial view to assess spatial relations and candidate impacts.
Inputs: User interaction (click on TRV arrow icon)
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.1.5: The TRV in viewpoint-major mode features an arrow-icon, which if clicked changes the perspective of the 3D spatial view to match the perspective of the selected viewpoint.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Hovering on a candidate or viewpoint in TRV, filmstrip, or 3D view highlights the corresponding entity across all views for coordinated exploration.
Inputs: Hover events from TRV, 3D spatial view, or filmstrip
Outputs: Highlighted candidates or viewpoints across coordinated views
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.1.1: Peek-brush interaction... shows the occurrence of the respective candidate in all other VIM distributions by showing the candidateâ€™s letter in the stacked bar chart.

GranularBlocks.PaperDescription: Selecting elements in TRV triggers updates in the 3D spatial view (viewpoint navigation and candidate highlight) and in the filmstrip for qualitative inspection.
Outputs: Synchronized view updates in 3D spatial view and filmstrip
GranularBlocks.ReferenceCitation: Section 7.1.5: The ranking, the filtering, and the peek-selection are coordinated with the 3D spatial view and the filmstrip.
